Shanghai, Sept. 27, 1934.
Dear Family:
It seens as though I never
to you until
I take a trip somewhere away from the office.
My last letter was from
the SS Hoover and this one is fron the A.s.
(air ship) Tientsin enroute
from Shanghai
to Felping•
We left Lunghws Field at 6:30 a.m. and now
are 40
minutes we are crossing the Yangtaze near a plece where the
Shanghailanders Interested in boating used to have an annual regatta.
The foreigners dubbed the place Henly
and now it appears on Chinese
maps as REN-LI.
our plane is a Stinson six place
co-pilot and
four passergers) monoplane powered with a Curtiss
The ship has a cruising speed of about 105 miles per hour.
@ hope soon to replace this equipment with
twin motor Lockheed Electras
carrying pilot, copilot, ten passengers and cruising at 200 miles per
hour •
Now we are flying three round trips
planes will fly a daily schedule.
To return
to this particular. trip-
week but with the new
the pilot is white and the
Ite funny to hear him speak
perfedly good Chicago Inglish with all
the slang phrases which any Amer-
i can boy
normally uses in lieu of a facility for expression in
good English.
The copilot's name is Wong.
There are two
passengers in the cabin
with me whose names are also Wong.
In fact Wong in
Chinese is about like
Cohen in New York only more so.
duced
to 8 or 10 more wongs exclaimed, "VIrty million chinamen
friends after having been intro-
can't be
Wong•"
we have been flying
through low clouds and rain but now the
celling has lifted and visibility is unlimited as we fly at 2ê 2000 feet
in bright sunshine, occasionally
curl right back just like it wes when she left the electrio chair but
my kind of pormanent (Permanently gone) is not affected.
Baok home you
can figure
the wind direction and velooity at the altitude you are flying
by timing
the shadows of olouds as
quilt of shapelesa patchos of
green and brown.
However our pilots get
the upper sir readinga
The weather expert sends up balloons
with specially designed instruments plots the wind direction and
velocity at different altitudes.
Frequently
you may have for example -
a 10 mile head wind at 1000 feet while at 5000
there nay be a follow-
ing wind.
He are now approaching Haichow.
I hope we will be more
oessful in finding it than you will be if you try to look it up on a map
because it's not on many mapa.
We found it all right and had lots of exeitement.
There are a few bare-
foot soldiers stationed at the field to keep peace and erder (that's a
mistake there is no order in China) anyway to keep
peace.
to walk across the field and the
soldiers told them not to do so.
The farmers made monkey faces at the soldiers and you've never, or
hear such "walla walla" or "makie talkee".
The women were the
The farmers and farmerettes plus the minions of the law had a
verbal
pitched battle and finally in defiance of the soldiers the erowd
across the field,
whereupon one of the soldiers shot once over
the heads of
the crowd.
The ferners dispersed - every man and woman
for him or her self - and that was
we took off all was quiet on the western and all other fronts and
field was clear.
